My name is Canwen, and I play
both the piano and the violin.

47.26.text:
I moved to the United States

50.08.text:
so almost my entire life

56.65.text:
I'm addicted to orange chicken,

61.69.text:
But having grown up in North Dakota,
South Dakota, and Idaho,

64.97.text:
all states with incredible
little racial diversity,

68.32.text:
it was difficult to reconcile
my so-called exotic Chinese heritage

75.55.text: Used to being the only Asian in the room,

78.28.text:
I was self-conscious at the first thing
people noticed about me

83.45.text: And as a child I quickly began to realize

86.08.text: that I had two options in front of me.

88.85.text:
Conformed to the stereotype
that was expected of me,

91.88.text:
or conformed to the whiteness
that surrounded me.

98.31.text:
For me, this meant that I always felt
self-conscious about being good at maths,

102.12.text:
because people would just say
it was because I was Asian,

105.21.text: not because I actually worked hard.

107.82.text:
It meant that whenever
a boy asked me out,

110.03.text: it was because he had the yellow fever,

112.35.text: and not because he actually liked me.

115.79.text: It meant that for the longest time

117.88.text:
my identity had formed
around the fact that I was different.

121.43.text:
And I thought that being Asian
was the only special thing about me.

126.52.text:
These effects were emphasized
by the places where I lived.

130.58.text:
Only a small percentage
of people were actually racist,

135.96.text:
but the vast majority were
just a little bit clueless.

140.31.text:
Now, I know you are probably thinking,
"What's the difference?"

"I'm white, you're not,

163.10.text: Now, I don't doubt for a second

165.09.text:
that these clueless people

But they do ask some questions

177.86.text:
"You're Chinese, oh my goodness,

Because contrary

So, just an FYI for all of you out there,

But, as amusing
as these interactions were,

297.84.text:
oftentimes they made me
want to reject my own culture,

300.54.text: because I thought it helped me conform.

303.85.text:
I distanced myself
from the Asian stereotype

306.50.text:
as much as possible,
by degrading my own race,

312.24.text: And the worse part was, it worked.

316.12.text:
The more I rejected my Chinese identity,
the more popular I became.

320.97.text:
My peers liked me more,
because I was more similar to them.

325.14.text:
I became more confident,
because I knew I was more similar to them.

331.27.text: But as I became more Americanized,

334.15.text:
I also began to lose
bits and pieces of myself,

336.52.text: parts of me that I can never get back,

338.64.text: and no matter how much I tried to pretend

341.06.text:
that I was the same
as my American classmates,

346.39.text:
Because for people who have lived
in the places where I lived,

350.40.text:
white is the norm, and for me,
white became the norm too.

355.60.text:
For my fourteenth birthday,
I received the video game The Sims 3,

358.92.text:
which lets you create your own characters
and control their lives.

362.98.text:
My fourteen-year-old self created
the perfect little mainstream family,

366.47.text:
complete with a huge mansion
and an enormous swimming pool.

371.10.text:
I binge-played the game
for about three months,

373.41.text:
then put it away and never
really thought about it again,

377.39.text: when I came to a sudden realization.

380.24.text:
The family, that I had custom-designed,
was white.

383.97.text:
The character that I had designed
for myself, was white.

388.05.text: Everyone I had designed was white.

392.76.text:
this was by no means
a conscious decision that I had made.

396.38.text: Never once did I think to myself

398.16.text:
that I could actually make
the characters look like me.

402.22.text:
Without even thinking,
white had become my norm too.

409.25.text:
Asian Americans play a strange role
in the American melting pot.

417.12.text:
Society uses our success to pit us
against other people of color

421.25.text:
as justification
that racism doesn't exist.

425.62.text:
But was does that mean
for us, Asian Americans?

430.09.text:
It means that we are not quite
similar enough to be accepted,

433.03.text:
but we aren't different enough
to be loathed.

435.46.text: We are in a perpetually grey zone,

437.10.text:
and society isn't quite sure
what to do with us.

440.40.text: So they group us by the color of our skin.

443.58.text:
They tell us that we must reject
our own heritages,

446.02.text: so we can fit in with the crowd.

448.53.text: They tell us that our foreignness

450.48.text:
is the only identifying 
characteristic of us.

454.03.text: They strip away our identities one by one,

456.69.text:
until we are foreign,
but not quite foreign,

463.65.text:
but only when there are no other people
from our native country around.

469.65.text:
I wish that I had always had the courage
to speak out about these issues.

475.09.text:
But coming from one culture
that avoids confrontation,

478.24.text: and another that is divided over race,

481.27.text:
how do I overcome the pressure
to keep the peace,

484.20.text: while also staying true to who I am?

487.33.text:
And as much as I hate to admit it,
often times I don't speak out,

493.08.text:
it's at the the risk of being told
that I am too sensitive,

496.67.text: or that I get offended too easily,

498.93.text: or that it's just not worth it.

503.08.text:
But I would point,
are people willing to admit that?

509.56.text:
But that's precisely the reason
why we need to talk about them.

516.53.text:
and there are still so many things
that I don't know about the world.

519.80.text:
But what I do know
is that it's hard to admit

522.18.text: that you might be part of the problem,

524.02.text:
that, all of us
might be part of the problem.

527.13.text:
So, instead of giving you
a step-by-step guide

529.67.text: on how to not be racist towards Asians,

532.72.text:
I will let you decide
what to take from this talk.

My name is Canwen,
